citation.article-title: Clostridium disporicum sp. nov., a saccharolytic species able to form two spores per cell, isolated from rat cecum.

p.s: Description of Clostridium disporicum sp. nov.
Clostridium disporicum (di.spor´i.cum. Gr. pref. di, two; Gr. n. sporos, seed; Gr. suffix, ikos, pertaining to; N. L. neut. adj., disporicum, pertaining to [or possessing] two spores)
Cells are rod shaped and 1.5 μm wide by 2.5 to 10 μm long.
They are obligately anaerobic, gram positive, nonmotile, forming subterminal oval spores, and belong to the genus Clostridium.
Spores are formed in both ends of some cells.
Cells containing two spores are present in a lower proportion than cells with only one spore and form approximately 10 to 20% of the total population.
Examination by electron microscopy showed no evidence of incipient cell division or cross-wall formation in cells with two developing or fully developed spores (Fig. 2).
Anaerobic conditions are required for the growth of DS1T.
No growth occurs in a medium without fermentable carbohydrate.
The major products from peptone-yeast broth medium containing glucose (0.5%, wt/vol) are acetic and lactic acid with trace amounts of n-butyric and succinic acids (Table 1).
Production of short-chain fatty acids is greater in basal SM10 containing glucose (0.5%, wt/vol).
A small amount of ethanol is also formed in both media.
Moderate amounts of gas are produced.

The following carbohydrates are used by DS1T as carbon sources for growth and acid production: esculin, cellobiose, dulcitol, fructose, galactose, glucose, lactose, maltose, mannitol, mannose, melibiose, raffinose, ribose, salicin, starch, sucrose, trehalose, and xylose.
Esculin and starch are both hydrolyzed.
Arabinose , inositol, melezitose, rhamnose, and sorbitol are not utilized.
DS1T does not liquefy gelatin or digest cooked meat or casein in milk.
Lecithinase, lipase, and catalase activities are not present, and indole is not produced.
Reference strains NCIB 8052T and NCIB 9362T (Table 1) have a G+C content of 29 mol%.
Precise determination of the G+C content of DS1T (38 to 41 mol%) was made difficult by the general broadness of the peak obtained from density centrifugation.
Most Clostridium species have a G+C content close to 28 mol% (9); C. oceanicum has a G+C content of 27 to 28 mol%.
A second smaller group has a G+C content range from 40 to 54 mol% with C. nexile and C. sphenoides having a content close to that of DS1T at 40 to 41 and 41 to 42 mol%, respectively.
In other biochemical characteristics the latter strains have no similarity with DS1T (5).
One other Clostridium species, C. oceanicum, has been reported to produce cells containing two spores (20).
This species, however, unlike DS1T hydrolyzes gelatin, a major subdivision in the classification of Clostridium sp. (5).
Additionally, C. oceanicum does not ferment lactose, maltose, raffinose, starch, or sucrose, as does DS1T.

The morphological and biochemical characteristics of strain DS1T do not match the characteristics of other species in the genus Clostridium (5); it is therefore proposed to be a new species, Clostridium disporicum.
The type strain, DS1, has been deposited in the NCIB as no. 12424.
